name: Cat-Cow Stretch
description: A gentle flowing exercise to warm up the spine and relieve tension in the lower back.
instructions: Start on your hands and knees in a tabletop position
Inhale and arch your back, dropping your belly (Cow pose)
Exhale and round your spine, tucking your chin (Cat pose)
Continue flowing between these positions
tips: Move slowly and smoothly with your breath
warnings: Stop if you feel sharp pain
Avoid if you have recent back injury

name: Pelvic Tilt
description: Strengthens the lower back and core muscles while improving posture.
instructions: Lie on your back with knees bent and feet flat on the floor
Tighten your abdominal muscles
Flatten your lower back against the floor
Hold for 5 seconds, then relax
tips: Focus on using your core muscles

name: Bird Dog
description: Improves balance and strengthens the core and lower back stabilizer muscles.
instructions: Start on your hands and knees
Extend your right arm forward and left leg back simultaneously
Hold for 3-5 seconds keeping your core tight
Return to start and switch sides
tips: Focus on keeping your back straight

name: Child's Pose
description: A restorative stretch that gently elongates the spine and relieves tension.
instructions: Kneel on the floor with your big toes touching
Sit back on your heels
Extend your arms forward and lower your chest
Rest your forehead on the floor
tips: Breathe deeply and relax into the stretch
Place a pillow under your forehead if needed
warnings: Avoid if you have knee problems
Stop if you feel pain in your knees or hips

name: Knee to Chest
description: Stretches the lower back and helps relieve pressure on spinal nerves.
instructions: Lie on your back with knees bent
Bring one knee toward your chest
Hold for 5 seconds
Return to start and repeat with the other leg
tips: Pull gently, don't force the stretch
Keep your back flat on the floor
warnings: Stop if you feel pain radiating down your leg
Avoid if you have hip problems

name: Standing Back Extension
description: Strengthens the lower back muscles and improves posture.
instructions: Stand up straight with your feet shoulder-width apart
Place your hands on your lower back
Gently arch backward, looking up
Hold for 2-3 seconds, then return to upright
tips: Keep the movement gentle and controlled
Support your lower back with your hands
warnings: Stop if you feel sharp pain
Don't overextend if you have spinal stenosis

name: Seated Spinal Twist
description: Improves spinal mobility and relieves tension in the back.
instructions: Sit on the floor with legs extended
Bend your right knee and place foot over left leg
Twist to the right, placing left elbow outside right knee
Hold, then repeat on the other side
tips: Sit up tall throughout the stretch
Breathe deeply and twist a little deeper with each exhale
warnings: Move gently, don't force the twist
Avoid if you have disc herniation

name: Bridge Exercise
description: Strengthens the glutes, hamstrings, and lower back muscles.
instructions: Lie on your back with knees bent and feet flat
Lift your hips off the floor until body forms a straight line
Hold for 2-3 seconds
Lower back down slowly
tips: Squeeze your glutes at the top
warnings: Stop if you feel pain in your lower back
